Brief: Successful energy trading 
		requires discipline. Traders must not only have a market view, but also 
		a consistent, objective strategy to determine how and when to enter, 
		exit, and manage risk to let profits run and cut losses. This seminar is 
		designed to introduce traders to the basic mechanics of technical 
		trading. The first part of the class is an introduction to the basic 
		technical indicators and techniques. The latter part will focus on 
		practical application of trading strategies using real market data.
Attendees of both this seminar and its 
		sister seminar, Forecasting Using Technical Analysis, will receive $100 
		off the registration fee of both seminars.


       



Trading Technically ($695) 
		- CPE: TBA

      	Outline
1. Review of Technical 
		Indicators?
		a. Momentum.
		b. Stops
		c. Entry
		2. Entering a trade
		a. Types of Entry Signals
		i. Simple entry systems
		ii. More complex entries
		iii. Filtering with higher time frame
		b. Using multiple entry signals to confirm
		c. Second Signals
		d. Scaling in
		3. Exiting a trade
		a. Divergence
		b. Overbought Oversold
		c. Candlestick Exits
		d. Scaling out
		4. Stops and Stop Systems
		a. Types of Stops
		b. Fixed Price Stops
		c. Trailing Stops
		d. Using Stops to manage trade risk
		e. Using Stops with warning/exit signals
		5. Choosing a bar length
		a. Tick vs. Time
		b. Based upon trading style
		c. Based upon risk assessment
		d. Using multiple time frames
		6. Practice Sessions
		a. Standard Indicator Trading System
		b. Kase Indicator Trading System












? Cash market traders looking to better 
		timed purchases and sales 
		? For-profit traders looking for a disciplined method of trade execution 
		and exits 
		? Analysts who wish to add "charting" to their fundamental or 
		quantitative views 
		? Hedgers seeking insight as to the timing of short term hedges

		A question often asked is "I have no experience with technical analysis, 
		is this class for me?" The class begins with the basics of charting and 
		is designed for those who know what a futures contract is and perhaps 
		have some experience with the cash market or hedging but no knowledge of 
		technical trading.

		The class will teach techniques that will be helpful not only for those 
		who wish to trade futures for profit, but also for cash market 
		participants and hedgers who must time transactions.

		A typical class attendee has had some exposure to the market, usually on 
		the physical side, or as a support person, but lacks an understanding of 
		the technical. Those who do have experience trading futures, but need a 
		more rigorous, disciplined approach to doing so will find this class 
		gives them the structure to approach the markets more methodically. 
		Finally, those tasked with market analysis and forecasting will find the 
		analytical techniques taught helpful to developing a more accurate 
		market view.






P. Dean 
		Rogers - P. Dean Rogers studied computer science at the University 
		of New Mexico before joining Kase and Company, Inc. in early 2001 as a 
		programmer and became manager of the Kase Call Center in 2002. Rogers 
		has co-taught classes for both trading and hedging since that time and 
		is responsible for all client training in regards to trading and 
		hedging. He has also assisted Ms. Kase, president of Kase and Company, 
		Inc., with the weekly natural gas and forecast for five years, has 
		written the review of trading strategies and trading lessons, and is now 
		the primary forecaster of crude oil for Kase.
